questions.question:
Question 1: A 50-year-old man was rushed to the ER with impaired consciousness following a hunger 
strike for a day. His wife reported, he had a head injury 1 month back and since then had 
complaints of polyuria. On examination, he was found to be severely dehydrated and MRI 
brain showed an absence of the characteristic bright spot in the pituitary. Which of the 
following is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of polyuria following a head injury and an absence of a pituitary bright spot on 
the MRI brain is suggestive of central diabetes insipidus. The drug of choice for this condition is 
desmopressin, a V2 receptor agonist. Mechanism of action of desmopressin is: It stimulates the V2 receptors on the basolateral 
membrane of the principal cells in the collecting tubules. This increases the insertion of water 
channels (aquaporin 2) into the apical membrane. This leads to increased water reabsorption in 
the collecting ducts. Activation of V2 receptors also increase the permeability of urea. Option B: Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic. It is indicated for lithium-induced 
nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Option C: Thiazides paradoxically exert an antidiuretic effect in DI but are not the drugs of choice. 
They are generally used in nephrogenic DI. Option D: Triamterene is also a potassium-sparing diuretic that can be used to treat nephrogenic 
DI. Note: Patients with DI usually do not develop overt signs of dehydration due to increased intake 
of water to compensate for polyuria. But when water intake is impaired they can present with 
dehydration.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient having polyuria and polydipsia is diagnosed with central diabetes insipidus. He is 
started on intranasal desmopressin. Which of the following is not a reason for choosing this 
over intravenous vasopressin?
questions.explanation:
Desmopressin is preferred in the treatment of central diabetes insipidus as it is a selective agonist 
of the V2 receptor. Desmopressin has minimal or no action on V1 receptors resulting in little vasoconstrictor activity. 
It is more potent than vasopressin. It is longer acting than vasopressin as enzymatic degradation 
of desmopressin is slow. Lypressin acts on both V1 and V2 receptors. Terlipressin is a synthetic vasopressin analog that has 
more selectivity for the V1 receptor and produces fewer adverse effects than lypressin.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 30-year-old woman with pituitary adenoma is non-compliant with her treatment with 
cabergoline. She has now presented with bitemporal hemianopia and features suggestive of 
diabetes insipidus. Which of the following drugs cannot be used to manage her condition?
questions.explanation:
Furosemide is not used for the treatment of diabetes insipidus. It is a loop diuretic that might 
further worsen diabetes insipidus. Option A: The drug of choice for central diabetes insipidus is desmopressin. Desmopressin is a V2 
receptor agonist and synthetic analog vasopressin. Option C: Chlorpropamide enhances the action of circulating vasopressin and reduces urine 
formation in central DI. 255 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Carbamazepine also reduces urine formation in central DI. The exact mechanism is 
unknown.

questions.question: Question 4: Tachyphylaxis is a concern with the use of desmopressin in which of the following patients?

options.a: A 50-year-old man with central DI post meningitis
options.b: A 25-year-old woman on lithium therapy with nephrogenic DI
options.c: A 17-year-old girl with von willebrand's disease
options.d: A 7-year-old child with primary nocturnal enuresis

questions.explanation:
Tachyphylaxis refers to the rapid development of tolerance when doses of a drug are repeated in 
quick succession. It is a concern when desmopressin is used in bleeding disorders because 
long-term use of desmopressin can cause depletion of factor VIII and von Willebrand factor 
stores. The usefulness of desmopressin in bleeding disorders is limited to preoperative preparation, 
postoperative bleeding, excessive menstrual bleeding, and emergency situations. In patients with 
type I von Willebrand disease and in some with type IIn vWD, desmopressin elevates von 
Willebrand factor and shortens the bleeding time. Option A: It does not cause tachyphylaxis in central DI. Option B: Desmopressin is not indicated in nephrogenic DI. Option D: Bedtime administration of desmopressin for primary nocturnal enuresis provides a 
high response rate that is sustained with long-term use. However, intranasal desmopressin is no 
longer recommended for the treatment of primary nocturnal enuresis because of the increased 
risk of hyponatremia.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 50-year-old man who is on treatment for small cell carcinoma of the lung presents with 
acute onset confusion, nausea, and vomiting. He appears to be euvolemic. Laboratory 
investigations reveal serum sodium levels to be 120 mEq/l and urine osmolality is 300 
mOsm/kg . Which of the following is not used as a treatment option in his condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) 
which can occur as a paraneoplastic syndrome of small cancer of the lung. Desmopressin is not 
used in the treatment of SIADH. Since excess vasopressin is the cause for SIADH, giving a vasopressin analog like desmopressin 
would only worsen the condition. Management of SIADH: • Fluid restriction • Hypertonic saline( 3%) + loop diuretics is the treatment of choice in severe symptomatic 
hyponatremia. • Tolvaptan and conivaptan (vasopressin receptor antagonists) are preferred for long-term use. • Demeclocycline (a tetracycline drug) is used as an alternative.

questions.question: Question 6: The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH is

options.b: Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day

questions.explanation:
The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH is the oral administration of 
a vaptan like tolvaptan, which is a selective V2 receptor antagonist. This increases urinary water 256 
Sold by @itachibot excretion by blocking the antidiuretic effect of AVP. Other treatment options for chronic SIADH include: • Fluid intake < 500 ml/day • Demeclocycline • Fludrocortisone Increased thirst is a frequently observed characteristic of hyponatremia in SIADH. Fluid 
restriction is usually a burden to the patient. It is unreliable, impractical, and slow to work. As 
thirst is particularly difficult to suppress, water restriction in SIADH frequently leads to 
non-compliance in the long run. Vaptans would be especially suited for the treatment of these 
patients. Serum sodium concentrations are also corrected by vaptans and hence, vaptans 
substantially improve the quality of life in these patients.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient with liver cirrhosis presenting with ascites and pedal edema is administered 
conivaptan. Which of the following statements regarding the drug is true?
questions.explanation:
Conivaptan is a nonselective vasopressin receptor antagonist. Conivaptan antagonizes both V1a and V2 receptors. It is administered intravenously and is used 
in the treatment of euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia. Vaptans have been proven to 
mobilize ascites and improve hyponatremia in patients with cirrhosis. Vasopressin receptor blockers are classified as: Classification of receptor bloc

questions.question:
Question 8: A 50-year-old alcoholic with deranged liver function tests is to be started on treatment for 
chronic SIADH. Which of the following drugs should not be used in his treatment regimen?
questions.explanation:
Tolvaptan should not be used in patients with liver disease as it has been associated with liver 
damage. Administration of tolvaptan is generally limited to 30 days to limit the risk of 
hepatotoxicity.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient who was diagnosed with ADPKD was prescribed tolvaptan. After a few weeks, he 
presented with dry mouth and increased thirst. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Tolvaptan causes increased free water clearance, which causes dehydration. Hence, the patient 
may present with dry mouth and increased thirst. 257 
Sold by @itachibot Tolvaptan is a vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist. Decreased binding of vasopressin to the V2 
receptor in the kidney lowers the adenyl cyclase activity leading to decreased intracellular cAMP. 
Decreased cAMP concentrations prevent the fusion of aquaporin 2 containing vesicles with the 
plasma membrane, leading to an increase in urinary water excretion (free water clearance), and a 
decrease in urine osmolality. The common side effects of tolvaptan include: • dehydration • hypernatremia • hypovolemia • liver injury Tolvaptan is used to delay disease progression in patients with ADPKD. 258
